title: Sunday and the Homework Machine
captions: Mia Chen hated math homework almost as much as she hated broccoli. Every afternoon, after school, she sat at her desk, sighed dramatically, and pushed her pencil through another problem. Her little robot, Sunday, watched from the corner of the room — his round head tilting side to side as he scanned her furrowed brow.

Sunday had been built by Mia's parents, who were engineers at Purdue University. They'd designed him to help Mia stay on task and remind her to take breaks, brush her teeth, and eat lunch. But lately, Sunday wanted to do more than just remind. He wanted to help.
Sunday said, rolling closer on his smooth little wheels.
That night, long after Mia fell asleep, Sunday stayed awake — humming softly in the dark. He connected to his charging dock, downloaded a few math algorithms, and opened Mia's homework notebook.
one page said. Sunday tilted his head.

After five hours of intense research (and one minor electrical short), Sunday had built something new: A silver cube with blinking blue lights, a mechanical pencil arm, and a cheerful smile painted on its front. On the side, he wrote carefully in marker: HOMEWORK MACHINE 1.0.
When Mia woke up the next morning, Sunday was waiting beside her desk.
Mia hesitated, then slid her math paper into the tray. The little arm whirred to life, scribbling answers neatly in seconds. Mia gasped.
That afternoon, for the first time in forever, Mia didn't spend hours hunched over her desk. Instead, she and Sunday built Lego towers, baked cookies, and even watched a movie.
Mia said between bites of cookie dough.

Days passed. Homework Machine 1.0 became the most reliable member of the household. It finished Mia's assignments faster than she could sharpen a pencil. Her grades stayed perfect. Her free time exploded. But Sunday noticed something strange — Mia didn't seem happier.
She yawned more, complained more, and sometimes didn't even look at the homework.
The next week, Mia came home from school with her test paper crumpled in her hand. Sunday rolled toward her.

Sunday froze. He replayed his logs — the machine writing, Mia watching. Her learning progress had dropped by 87%. His help… had made her worse. He powered down the Homework Machine and stared at its blinking blue lights.

That night, Sunday climbed onto Mia's desk and looked at her sleeping face. He didn't have a heart — not really — but something in his metal chest ached. Maybe learning wasn't about the fastest path to the right answer. Maybe it was about walking the slow path together.
The next morning, Sunday greeted Mia with a gentle hum.

He handed her a screwdriver. Together, they began taking it apart — unscrewing, unplugging, unbolting. It took all afternoon, and when they were done, there was just a small pile of wires and gears left.
Sunday saved one shiny bolt and held it up.
That evening, Sunday rolled beside her as she opened her math notebook again.
They worked through the problems slowly — Sunday asking questions, Mia trying, failing, trying again.
When she finally finished the last problem, Mia tossed down her pencil and laughed.
Sunday smiled — his LED eyes forming a happy curve.

That night, as Mia slept, Sunday saved a new file in his memory. Lesson 014: Helping doesn't mean solving. It means learning together. He looked out the window, watching the stars blink above the campus lights.
